0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Develop testing and evaluation procedures.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Verify shipment details against commercial invoice, bill of lading, and other relevant documentation to ensure accuracy.
Obtain necessary licenses and permits for international shipments, including export and import certificates.
Coordinate with shipping lines and freight forwarders to arrange transportation and tracking of goods.
Conduct research on tariffs, quotas, and regulations affecting imported or exported goods to minimize compliance risks.
Prepare and submit required customs declarations, forms, and schedules in accordance with government regulations.
Collaborate with suppliers, manufacturers, and distributors to obtain necessary documentation and clearances for international shipments.
Monitor shipment status and track progress through various transportation modes, including air, land, and sea.
Negotiate with customs authorities and regulatory agencies on behalf of clients to resolve disputes or clarify regulations.
Maintain accurate records of shipments, including arrival and departure details, freight costs, and customs fees.
Ensure compliance with all relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards governing international trade and logistics.
Develop and implement effective strategies for mitigating customs-related risks and improving supply chain efficiency.
Stay up-to-date on changes to tariffs, quotas, and regulatory requirements that may impact client shipments.
Manage and resolve discrepancies or errors in customs documentation, such as missing or incorrect information.
Provide clients with expert advice and guidance on international trade regulations and compliance issues.
Develop and maintain relationships with suppliers, manufacturers, and distributors to build trust and improve supply chain collaboration.
Monitor market trends and economic conditions that may impact client shipments, including changes in demand, currency fluctuations, and global events.
Coordinate with customs brokers in other locations or countries to facilitate the clearance of international shipments.
Prepare and present reports on customs compliance, freight costs, and shipment performance to clients and internal stakeholders.
Establish and maintain effective communication channels with clients, suppliers, and regulatory agencies to ensure seamless customs clearance processes.
Review and analyze customer feedback and industry trends to identify areas for process improvement and optimization.
Ensure adherence to all relevant standards and best practices for customs brokerage, including those related to data security, confidentiality, and compliance.
1: Develop and implement training programs for employees, aligning with organizational goals and objectives.
Conduct needs assessments to identify areas where employees require skill development and training.
Design, develop, and deliver training materials such as presentations, handouts, and videos.
Coordinate and facilitate workshops, seminars, and other training events.
Evaluate the effectiveness of training programs through metrics such as participant feedback and skills assessment results.
Collaborate with subject matter experts to create high-quality training content.
Create and manage training budgets, ensuring cost-effective use of resources.
Identify and recruit external trainers or speakers to enhance training offerings.
Develop policies and procedures for training program delivery, including scheduling and logistics.
Provide coaching and mentoring support to employees to help them apply skills learned during training.
Maintain accurate records of employee training participation and progress.
2: Prepare ingredients for a large-scale catering event
Maintain cleanliness in the kitchen during food preparation
Cook meals according to institutional dietary requirements and regulations
Inventory stockroom supplies and order new items as necessary
Clean equipment, utensils, and other kitchen areas after use
Manage orders from clients and caterers to ensure timely delivery of prepared foods
Develop and implement a menu plan for a specific event or occasion
Maintain accurate records of food preparation and inventory levels
Ensure proper food storage, handling, and disposal procedures are followed
Prepare meals for special diets such as vegetarian or gluten-free
Attend meetings with staff to discuss menus, events, and new recipes
Monitor and maintain kitchen equipment to ensure optimal performance
